reviewText: I borrowed this dvd set from a friend after remembering that a lady I work with had told me once that it was so scary that she and her step-daughter had to turn it off (which I did not take to heart since this same woman was scared to go outside after watching the movie Van Helsing!).While this show is fun and yes, she was right, truly creepy at times, I have not been hooked the way most avid fans seem to be.  In general it is a bit too contrived, predictable and formulaic for me to hang on desperately for the next episode.  While I do like Jared Padalecki I have yet to be impressed by Jensen Ackles in any way.  I like Padalecki because of other work I have seen him do but even so the two cookie-cutter leads are just presented a little too much like men who have walked off the cover of a GQ magazine (in fairness, this is not really their fault).I think the reason I do not feel compelled to watch the show beyond the set I have borrowed is because I know that I can easily miss a few episodes and not truly have missed anything as far as the paper-thin running storyline goes which is bad because ultimately I don't care what happens to any of the characters and therefore I have no reason to want to tune in unless I have nothing better to do.  The very reason I am not addicted to the show is also an element that is not entirely bad.  Even if I had missed episodes here and there I CAN still tune in for an episode and enjoy it without frustration for the creepy atmosphere and solved-within-an-hour story of the week (please don't misunderstand this statement--I have watched the entire season, I am simply saying that looking back I certainly would not have had to see each episode in order to keep up with the goings on).The negatives:  The show suffers a bit in terms of the writing and the acting.  At first I forgave both because being a new series it is normal for it to be a bit rough at first, but as I continued to watch neither of these things improved much.  While this is not a show I feel is meant to be taken too seriously I still find the exposition in each episode to be nearing the side of ridiculousness.  I understand it is necessary but I also believe that better writers could find a way to pull it off in a less obvious manner.As far as the acting, a lot of the guest stars and one-episode characters are portrayed terribly and some are okay, even good.  My main issue with the acting is with Jensen Ackles.  While I understand that Padalecki is by no means some great actor I find him to be far more believable than Ackles, despite the opposite opinion that most Supernatural fans seem to hold.  I have actually laughed out loud many times upon Ackles' deliverance of lines and body language that are clearly supposed to be deadly serious but really just come off as silly and as though he doesn't even believe it.  Half the time it looks like he was trained at an acting school that teaches people how to act with nothing more than their eyebrows (think Jamie Foxx and Colin Farrell in "Miami Vice") except he purses his lips as well.  I keep waiting for him to say anything I can believe but sadly it has not happened yet.  I haven't seen anything beyond the first season, so maybe something has changed.The positives:  Where the show excels is atmosphere, setting and its soundtrack!  As I said early on, Supernatural is definitely creepy beyond any show I have seen on television and there have been times when I decided one episode was enough for the day because I can only take raised hackles for so long.  The sets are always well done and effective and the effects and makeup are also great, especially for TV.  If they could just transfer a bit of that effort into the writing and acting I think this show would be far better than it is.The music choices are refreshing and fun and while the songs played almost don't even seem to make sense given the age range of the target audience and style of the show they have been from some of my favorites (like Rush!) and I think add to the feel of it all.So, while this show is not the best out there by any means it is pretty unique and has potential, although I have to wonder whether that potential will ever be met since up to this point the flaws have not been fixed.Something has to be said for Supernatural's popularity as well.  What that something is...I am not sure.  Let's just say I almost felt the need to give a disclaimer at the beginning of my review to advise others that the review contains my own opinions which may be offensive to big Supernatural fans.  The following statements do not apply to every last Supernatural fan, so please don't take it that way, I know not everyone is like this.  That being said, a lot of the fan base for Supernatural seem to be almost cult-like in their love for this show, referring to Padalecki and Ackles as Jared and Jensen, like they know them personally and call them at home and even congratulating me on finally becoming one of them since I have seen the show finally.  WOW!  As you can see by looking on almost any site where there is discussion of the show the mentality is that this is THE best show ever made and anyone who does not agree that this is the "best show ever" is ripped to shreds--even here on Amazon, a specific looney toon goes to each negative review and writes a bunch of insane comments, even casts curses or "spells" on anyone who does not like the show.  Ah, to be 13 years old.  I am sure I will receive negative, childish comments about my review as well because it is not glowing and dares to mention flaws and *GASP* includes opinions that do not fall in line with die hard fans of Supernatural.  Oh well.

reviewText: While the series pilot had a plothole or two, on the whole it was a good introduction to the world of the Winchesters, a family of ghost and demon hunters who got into the business after a family tragedy. It also introduces us to the style of the series, and some continuing storylines involving family conflict, monsters of the week, their family's long running hunt for a mysterious killer, and Sam and Dean learning to deal with one another as brothers and hunting partners.The first season is rather uneven, focusing largely on cases the brothers find themselves on, with bits of family history woven in during the early episodes. Around midseason however the larger family arc starts kicking in and the season closes with several strong episodes where some long awaited issues get addressed and the final scenes lead to one of the strongest season cliffhangers around. You'll definitely want to start watching S2 once you get to the end.There are numerous deleted scenes here, marked by scissors icons on each episode they belong to.  Viewers also have the option of turning off the introductory recaps that are attached to each episode, (although one may want to keep the one for the season finale).  There are also some enjoyable commentaries, although one could have hoped for more, especially since they are for early episodes.  There are also some entertaining documentary features and, of course, the gag reel.  On the whole a good set.

reviewText: Supernatural exceeded my expectations in the first season. At first I was a bit cynical as there had been many other shows that had tried the supernatural angle and failed, but this series has been a surprising hit. The storylines are always compelling, and a mixture of ghostly phenomena, apparitions, and even urban myths. The acting is well above average. We have the older Winchester brother played excellently by Jensen Ackles, and the younger brother Sam, played by Gilmore Girls alum, Jared Padalecki. Both characters portray their struggles & inner conflicts really well, and the two main leads share a genuine on-screen chemistry, making us sympathise with their plight in trying to locate their father.There is also a unique quality to this series...the dark storylines juxtaposed with the humor & wit contained within the dialogues...it makes for enjoyable viewing every episode!
